discussion.content: CCDE book Table 3-4, Public Cloud is 'Lowest cost' and there are several migration of goverment system to public cloud these days. so It should be Public Cloud.

Selected Answer: D
Government related and tight data governance rules is the most impostant. Data cannot be "public". On-prem and private-cloud are the only solutions, where private-cloud can lower the cost. Answer D is more appropiate.

comments.content: But that capex would be lower than on-prem due to the efficiency of cloud
private cloud incurs capex, which should be minimized according to the question.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Public cloud is the most suitable in this scenario because it offers a cost-effective way to scale IT resources without the need for significant upfront capital investment.

Selected Answer: A
Cost is the main driver. Data governance is not mentioned in the question despite it being government. This is a pre-conceived notion. AWS have standards and regulations for European government. Data governance is of course a valid concern for some use cases, but not the one within this question as its not explicitly mentioned.

Selected Answer: A
Public cloud is the "lowest cost". We are not talking about anything else in this question.

Selected Answer: A
it can be secure enough for government entities to use public cloud services, provided that proper security measures, compliance practices, and policies are in place. Many public cloud providers now offer highly secure environments and certifications to meet stringent governmental and regulatory requirements.

Several governments around the world have adopted public cloud solutions for various use cases, leveraging the scalability, cost efficiency, and security capabilities of public cloud providers.

Selected Answer: D
Private cloud because it maintains high security standards and it has the same flexibility as a public cloud

Correct answer is A. There is no mention of security in the question but there is to increase performance, flexibility and reduce capital expenses and IT staff - which Public cloud offers. On prem and private cloud do not allow for staff reduction and flexibility

Selected Answer: D
on-prem is out because of requirement to reduce IT staff
public cloud is out because of government data must be secure and regulatory requirements.
Hybrid combines on-premises infrastructure with a public cloud so out because of above reasons.
Only leaves Private cloud
Private cloud same as on-premise - so public cloud seems the right answer(A)

note that private cloud can be deployed in a public cloud also. azure is s good example. This solution offers reduction in capex, security and low cost. It is an opex model since it it based on subscription. D makes sense

Selected Answer: B
The key requirements are performance, workload flexibility and CAPEX reduction along with unspoken requirement that this is passport agency and therefore government related and most probably with tight data governance rules. I would say hybrid to keep data in-house and still have room to improve flexibility and reduce CAPEX.

Public cloud is the most expensive over time. Private cloud and on-premise provide no reduction in CAPEX or IT Staff. Therefore the best solution to mitigate all 3 is hybrid cloud and save where it makes sense without the full OPEX expenditure of the public cloud

I think answer should be B
It is expensive than public cloud but cheaper than private cloud, and it can provide high security for government sensitive data

Private clouds are costlier than Public clouds but cheaper than on-premise.
Still I feel the answer here is Private Cloud because its a government passport agency we are talking about and security is always questioned in Public clouds.
I think the key phrase is "reduce capital expenses."

comments.content: opposite. Private cloud is very expensive. AWS, Google or Microsoft would be an ideal solution

discussion.content: Isn't it private cloud? Public cloud is very expensive.

questions.question_text: A European government passport agency considers upgrading its IT systems to increase performance and workload flexibility in response to constantly changing requirements. The budget manager wants to reduce capital expenses and IT staff and must adopt the lowest-cost technology. Which technology choice is suitable?

A European national bank considers migrating its on-premises systems to a private cloud offering in a non-European location to significantly reduce IT costs. What is a primary factor prior to migration?

comments.content: Support. Political issue is the highest priority and mandatory.

discussion.content:
D
Organisations which receive and hold any of regulated data types to follow the GDPR requirements. According to GDPR, companies have to keep the data secure inside the EU and if the data is to be transferred outside of the UE, then it can only be transferred to countries or organisations that have signed up to equivalent privacy protection.
https://incountry.com/blog/data-residency-laws-by-country-overview/

Selected Answer: D
Refer vn mentioned below, political issue is the highest priority and mandatory.
When considering moving out the data, you need to consider the place allowed, rather than how to move or store. Even you have a very high security to protect data, if the government don't allowed you to place in the desired country, then you still cannot do that.

Selected Answer: D
D. the keyword is from Europe to Non-Europe location. Laws and Regulations matter most.
If in order of requirements, then conforming to banking laws will be the top priority. The other items are also important, but D comes first.
It's A. Prior to anything else

comments.content: moreover latency comparision is between cloud and on prem, all of bank customers are coming from internet so the best you can offer is based on the on prem internet connectivity. so answer from my understanding is A "security

discussion.content: Man its bank, so GDPR / PCI DSS is a must, when you move from europe to non europe location not none of them will be enforced by defualt, you need to find compliance based on cotract. so certainly security is the primary factor. latency will be there but security shall be the major concern.
I will pick C over D because for sure there will be additional latency. However, the data governance is probably taken care of.
It's D

Selected Answer: A
I think A

choices.B: Replace any electrical links with optical links.
choices.C: Increase memory on the branch switch.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
fragmenting data prevents HOL blocking

Selected Answer: AE
I think fragmentation increases packet latency, affect voice quality.

comments.content: it is fragmenting data packets and not voice. It is a technique so that the processing the data packet does not delay voice packets in the queue

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
I think the trick is "high latency" on this wan link, if latency is high, increase bandwidth won't do any help. eg: you got some big data packet, like 9192 bytes, already in queue, the next voice package must wait for this to be transmitted, but if you fragment the data packet, voice packet and be transferred immediate after a small data frame is sent. 
Don't think about the re-transmission or CPU utilization, the question doesn't ask us to think that comprehensive/detail.

Selected Answer: AD
fragment DATA packet, so voice can be transmitted during large data packet transfer, which improve the quality

Selected Answer: AD
From Cisco doc:
. If non-real-time data packets are fragmented into smaller frames, they are interleaved with real-time (voice) frames. In this way, both voice and data frames can be carried together on low speed links without causing excessive delay to the real-time voice traffic.

Selected Answer: AE
AE are correct, fragmentation will add serialization delay

fragmentation can lead to more retransmission of lost fragments and therefore affect the already bad link in a negativ way. Increase BW is the magical cure to everything QoS related and Voice Prioritization is a no brainer.

Answers AE

questions.question_text: Which two actions ensure voice quality in a branch location with a low-speed, high-latency WAN connection? (Choose two.)

choices.D: call management analysis to identify CAC failures and call quality issues
choices.A: active monitoring via synthetic probes to measure loss, latency, and jitter
choices.E: flow-based analysis to measure bandwidth mix of applications and their flows
choices.F: flow-based analysis with PTP time-stamping to measure loss, latency, and jitter
choices.B: call management analysis to identify network convergence-related failures
choices.C: passive monitoring via synthetic probes to measure loss, latency, and jitter

questions.question_text: Which three tools are used for ongoing monitoring and maintenance of a voice and video environment? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ADE
Need to identify CAC failures and call quality, active monitoring for loss, latency, and jitter, and flow based analysis to look at APP flows

comments.content: It conflicts with A or C.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ADF
Based on provided answers active monitoring will take care of measuring loss, latency, so we would need flow-based analysis to measure bandwidth mix of applications

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Traffic was equally balanced between Layer 3 links on core switches SW1 and SW2 before an introduction of the new video server in the network. This video server uses multicast to send video streams to hosts and now one of the links between core switches is over utilized. Which design solution solves this issue?

choices.E: Apply a more granular load-balancing method on SW1.
choices.C: Apply a more granular load-balancing method on SW2.
choices.D: Filter IGMP joins on an over-utilized link.
choices.B: Add more links between core switches.
choices.A: Aggregate links using Layer 2 link aggregation.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Answer is C..By applying a more granular load-balancing method on SW2, you can ensure that traffic is more evenly distributed between the Layer 3 links, preventing one link from becoming over-utilized due to the new multicast video traffic. This method would help optimize the traffic distribution across available links and address the issue without necessarily requiring additional physical resources.

Selected Answer: E
E. the ip multicast mulitpath command should apply to the router near the receiver end.

Selected Answer: E
i voted E
ECMP multicast load spitting has to be enable on the receivers gateway router in this SW1 that is the one doing rpf to find links going to the source

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/12_4t/ip_mcast/configuration/guide/mctlsplt.html#wp1055334

Selected Answer: C
ECMP multicast load splitting method based on source, group, and next-hop address--You can configure ECMP multicast load splitting using the ip multicast multipath command with the s-g-hash and next-hop-based keywords. (multicast multipath)
Single link is utilised as RPF check has been on single L3 Interface. How Layer 3 RPF check can get redistributed over layer2 link aggregation.

Selected Answer: A
it's coz of RPF, need either a GRE tunnel or L2 aggregation

comments.content:
The key is multicast and "streamS", one video stream is 1 channel (ip/port), so it will be multiple IP/Port pairs for all the streams coming from the server.
Changing the hashing at SW2 is the correct answer.

discussion.content: IP multicast Multipath only split load from more than one source, in this case, there is only one source neither E or C is correct as traffic will still Continuing To hit overutilized link. A is correct

Selected Answer: E
ip multicast multipath applies to the device which is closer to the receiver. So if this question is about this command, then the answer is E.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/12_4t/ip_mcast/configuration/guide/mctlsplt.html
"Be sure to enable the ip multicast multipath command on the router that is supposed to be the receiver for traffic from more than one incoming interfaces, which is opposite of unicast routing. From the perspective of unicast, multicast is active on the sending router connecting to more than one outgoing interfaces."

Selected Answer: A
With no L2 aggregation the only option is ECMP load splitting, and it's not load balancing.

comments.content: the aggregation is L2 though as per A

in my opinion, "ip multicast multipath" should apply on both SW1 and SW2 according official document. 
And the default loadbance of the portchannel with IP is ip and l4port.
Nexus9000# show port-channel load-bal
 System config: 
 Non-IP: src-dst mac 
 IP: src-dst ip-l4port rotate 0
No need to use default value. You can change the load balance method after aggregration. A is more appropriate.

discussion.content: I have done some more reading andsince the links are already L3, we can use "ip multicast multipath" on SW2 to do the load balancing. Layer 2 etherchannel will not help as the default load balancing hash is src-mac. C is the way to go then.
I think C makes sense

comments.content: A makes more sense. The outgoing interface from SW2 will be the port-channel and the hashing algorithm will take care of the load balancing

Correct the answer maybe only A
https://www.cisco.com/c/zh_cn/support/docs/ip/ip-multicast/16450-mcastguide0.html#anc17

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I think C
